# Task 1 

We want to know if having siblings affects a relationship between wake up time and exercise
We expect that people without siblings will read more if they excercise less and that people with siblings will read more as they excercise more. 
```{r}
setwd("/Users/carlaleone/Desktop/Exeter/Problem Sheet")
library(readr)
data <- read_csv("BIOM4025_data_2024.csv")
View(data)

data$age<- 2024 -  data$`Year of birth`
data$commute<- (data$`Commute today` + data$`Commute yesterday`)/ 2
data$siblings<- ifelse(data$Brothers > 0 | data$Sisters > 0, "Yes", "No")
data$books<- data$`Number of books per month`
data$wakeup<- data$`Waking up time`
data$siblings<- ifelse(data$Brothers == 11 | data$Sisters > 0, "Yes", "No")
data$n_siblings<- as.numeric(data$Brothers + data$Sisters)
 
hist(data$n_siblings)

```

# Task 2

Modelling. 

```{r}
model1<- glm(Exercise ~ n_siblings*Breakfast,family=poisson, data = data)
summary(model1)

model2<- glm(Exercise ~ n_siblings+ Breakfast,family=poisson, data = data)
summary(model2)

exercise_fitted<- predict(model1)
plot(Exercise ~ n_siblings, data, cex.lab=1.2, col="grey", font.lab=2, pch=19, 
     xlab="Number of Siblings", ylab="Exercise")
lines(exercise_fitted[order(data$Exercise)] ~ sort(data$Exercise))
```

```{r}
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
plot(model1)
```
